ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hidden Hearing Loss (Cochlear Synaptopathy)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by normal standard audiogram but difficulty in noise, reduced ABR Wave I amplitude, elevated ECochG SP/AP ratio, and extended high-frequency hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: (Central) Auditory Processing Disorder
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to speech-in-noise difficulties, but ruled out as most behavioral APD tests (dichotic, temporal processing) were normal.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meniere's Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Elevated SP/AP ratio is consistent with endolymphatic hydrops, but patient lacks vertigo or fluctuating low-frequency hearing loss.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess speech understanding in quiet and loudness tolerance.
Evaluate neural integrity given reflex abnormalities.
Assess binaural interaction at the brainstem level.
Investigate cochlear damage beyond standard frequencies.
Investigate cochlear potentials and SP/AP ratio for synaptopathy.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Standard audiometry revealed normal hearing sensitivity and excellent speech recognition in quiet, but acoustic reflexes were abnormal (elevated or absent). ABR showed reduced Wave I amplitudes and slightly elevated Wave V thresholds despite normal MRI/CT (ordered by neuro-otology). DPOAEs were intact, suggesting normal outer hair cell function.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal limits bilaterally; PTA 5 dB HL (Left) and 10 dB HL (Right).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: WRS excellent (98% L, 90% R); LDLs high (105 dB HL L, 100 dB HL R).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Abnormal; ipsilateral present only at 500/1000 Hz (100 dB HL), absent at high frequencies; contralateral absent.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Wave V present but thresholds slightly elevated (40-50 dB nHL); Wave I amplitudes reduced.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Specialized testing confirmed significant deficits in speech-in-noise (QuickSIN) and auditory figure-ground, alongside moderate extended high-frequency hearing loss. ECochG revealed abnormally large SP/AP ratios. Other APD tests (MLD, RGDT, dichotic) were normal, supporting a diagnosis of Hidden Hearing Loss rather than generalized APD.

tests.name: SCAN-3:A (APD Screening)
tests.result_summary: Gap detection and Competing Words normal; Auditory Figure-Ground (0 dB SNR) abnormal.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise (QuickSIN)
tests.result_summary: Significant SNR loss: 15.5 dB (Left) and 14.5 dB (Right).

tests.name: Masking Level Difference (MLD)
tests.result_summary: Normal binaural release from masking (9 dB at 500 Hz, 8 dB at 1000 Hz).

tests.name: Extended High-Frequency Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Moderate hearing loss at 12-16 kHz; thresholds 40-55 dB HL.

tests.name: Electrocochleography (ECochG)
tests.result_summary: Abnormally large SP/AP amplitude ratios: 0.48 (Left) and 0.53 (Right).

proposed_items: Use of hearing protection (earplugs) in noisy environments like concerts
Monitoring volume of personal listening devices (PLDs)
Use of Frequency Modulation (FM) system in classroom
counseling_actions: Counseling on the nature of Hidden Hearing Loss and cochlear synaptopathy
Education on noise-induced damage and conservation
Self-advocacy strategies for difficult listening situations

escalation.rationale_short: Patient was already cleared by neuro-otology (normal MRI/CT); ongoing management is audiologic.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor conventional and extended high-frequency thresholds and assess benefit of management strategies.

expected_outcome: Conventional and Extended High-Frequency Audiometry (3-month follow-up): No changes in thresholds compared to baseline.
Patient reported significant improvement in speech understanding in noisy environments following management strategies and auditory training.
Patient successfully uses an FM device and self-advocacy strategies at school.
